subject: Data
title: Astronomy's Data Tsunami
description: A quick, practical guide to Astronomy's Data Tsunami.

hook.text: The upcoming Vera Rubin Observatory will photograph the entire visible sky every three nights.

buildup.text: It will generate 20 terabytes of data per night â€” more than all previous astronomical surveys combined.

discovery.text: Astronomers can no longer look at images manually. Machine learning must classify millions of objects.

twist.text: Citizen science projects like Galaxy Zoo recruit volunteers to classify galaxies the algorithms miss.

climax.text: Astronomy went from pointing telescopes at single stars to scanning the entire universe with data.

punchline.text: We now have more sky data than astronomers to study it.

quiz.question: How often will the Vera Rubin Observatory photograph the entire visible sky?
